item.name: Alhambra
item.comment:
My wife enjoys this one more than I do. It's an ok game. A great deal of luck, which I don't really mind, usually. It's very easy to teach and it so far has gone over pretty well with everyone we have taught. It also plays pretty quickly.
It's fun trying to balance out your buildings to score points but if the building you need isn't available, tough luck. Now on player two's turn there are three of that building suddenly. Zero chance they will still be there when it's your turn again. Tough luck again. Sometimes it just feels like you are either destined to win or lose regardless of your choices, which is of course all luck.
A fairly fun game that is quick and easy to learn. Quite a bit of luck involved.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment:
After two plays:
So far I find myself thoroughly enjoying this game. I really like the auction aspect of the game. I think it's handled very nicely. The auction is certainly better the more players there are but most are.
There are many, many ways to score points thus many strategies that can be used. I like having that variety.
It actually moves fairly quickly with what felt like little downtime.
It's quite easy to learn and teach. I find it to be very enjoyable. The more the merrier with this one.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: An interesting game. Takes some planning to get as many of your buildings out for free as possible. It can get nasty when other players disrupt your well laid plans by building next to you! (which is a good thing) Not a lot of depth to the game but it's fun to play from time to time.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment:
I guess this one is a "classic" in my circle of friends. We have been playing it for 20 years or so now.
Very luck driven. You can watch your vastly superior force go splat as your dice refuse time and time again to roll anything even remotely good. However, there is certainly strategy and skill involved in deciding what to buy, where to send it, and whether or not to attack/defend various regions.
Very long game, definitely a full day sort of activity. Eventually, after many plays, you will find that people fall into predictable strategies because there are a handful that just plain work and many that just plain don't.
It's luster has definitely dulled for me over the years but I must say I still enjoy breaking it out once or twice a year even after all this time.

item.name: Axis & Allies: Pacific
item.comment:
As much as we have enjoyed Axis and Allies, we just really haven't cared for this one. We found it boring and very unbalanced.
As for the unbalanced part, I can certainly admit that perhaps we haven't played it enough to developed a proper strategy to pull out a victory with the allies....but we have played it four or five times now. How long does one have to play before the game "plays properly"? If it's possible to win as the allies it just isn't worth the time to learn how because it wasn't that much fun to begin with.
Some people seem to really enjoy it..just not my game group.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment: A classic. My wife still enjoys an occasional game of backgammon. We rarely play it now because we have so many other interesting games but I foresee it always getting a play or two a year at least!

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment:
A very light game.
We have enjoyed it a great deal though. It's clean, fast, and very simple to learn/teach. I've read about possible endgame stalmates that break the game but we have played maybe 30-40 times and it thus far has never happened to us.
The game can play as friendly or as confrontationally as you would like. If you don't like conflict in your games, play your cards sololy on your side of the board. If you like to make your spouse cringe a bit, play your cards on their side!
A great little game.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: comments pending. Need more plays to formulate a review.

item.name: Battleship
item.comment: I have fond memories of this one. Pure luck but still an interesting diversion for 15-20 minutes. Easy enough to be played with children.

item.name: Bell-Bottomed Badassses on the Mean Streets of Funk
item.comment: Pointless. About 10 minutes of moderate enjoyment reading some of the cards but there is really no game at all here.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
Beyond Balderdash
item.comment:
An ok game. Plays best in "the right group" of people. You get a bunch of people that are willing to get into the moment and have a good time it can be a pretty fun experience.
Not my favorite party game by any means.

item.name: Boggle
item.comment: Just not my thing. The only word game I ever really enjoyed was scrabble.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
Highly enjoyable. My wife and I have as much fun playing 2 player as we do multiplayer.
A very easy game but a very difficult game to teach. The mechanics aren't difficult but for some reason it is hard to teach to people. It's also a little difficult to show them how fun it will be when they learn...a little hard sometimes convincing your beer swilling pals that this little "bean game" is going to be worth their while to learn.
If you can overcome the cutesy theme and the "not hard but tricky" mechanics/strategies of the game it's a real blast to play. It has become a family favorite and it's one of the few that my mother will actually request.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
My first few games of this, I didn't get it. I understood the game rules..I just didn't really see the fun. However, after a few more plays (my wife loved it immediately) I started to understand some more of the overall strategy and see some opportunities for mischief. It has since become a great favorite amongst even my rough and tumble collection of football pals. They love stealing properties from each other or what they call "backdooring".
There's not a great deal of strategy to be had but for whatever reason we always have a good time and there is always a lot of laughter at the table when this comes out.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: A nice addition. Nothing unbalancing that we have seen thus far.

item.name: Carcassonne: The River
item.comment: Doesn't really seem to add much. At best it sort of divides the playing field into two parts, maybe limiting the size of the farming field someone might have otherwise have achieved.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment:
This has been a surprise hit with our group.
It's light, fast, and super easy to learn/teach.
It has an interesting mechanic for movement and card drawing. There are some very interesting decisions and strategies available and nobody ever seems to be completely out of the game until the very end.
Not a lot of depth but a great filler game!

item.name: Checkers
item.comment:
I grew up playing this with my grandfather.
I never liked it even then, but it was an excuse to spend time with him. Just never saw the fun in this one.

item.name: Chess
item.comment:
I enjoy chess but I find that one has to really keep ones hand in to maintain any sort of technical level of expertise in it. Any time I step away from the game for a year or so I notice a distinct drop in my level of play upon returning.
It's a classic and should be taught to every youngster, but to ever really be good at chess you have to make it your life.

item.name: Chinese Checkers
item.comment: An enjoyable family game. Not much strategy and almost no depth, but it's one that the entire family, regardless of age, can play and have a good time with.

item.name: Clue
item.comment:
I always kinda liked clue for whatever reason. Yes, the dice can be a pain and it's not that hard to figure out the culprit but it always appealed to me. I really have to track down more advanced/more modern clue-like games and try them.
Little depth but a nice little deduction game that even younger kids can participate in.

item.name: Cranium
item.comment:
It's a party game. If you expect anything other than that you WILL be disappointed.
That having been said...we enjoy this game. It has all aspects of all the "classic" party games rolled into it: pictionary, trivia pursuit, charades, name that tune...heck..you even get to play with clay!
Some people don't like pictionary because they think they can't draw but they may be very good at charades. This party game has a little something to match everyones strong points. There is a category that everyone can feel like they contribute to the team with.
A very light fun party game that feels a lot like "party games greatest hits"

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment:
My wife's family is very big on cribbage so I have been trying to learn and appreciate it. I certainly enjoy every game I play of it but I never ask/want to play it when we aren't with her family. It takes (for me) a great deal of practice to learn all the different scoring combos/sequences.
Not a bad game, just not my favorite.

item.name: Doom: The Boardgame
item.comment:
A surprise hit with my wife. I wasn't sure she would enjoy either the mechanics or the theme, but she is forever demanding to play it much to my delight.
I enjoy both sides. The invaders are fun but will almost always win so they are sometimes not as satisfying to play. The marines will almost always lose. I don't however believe that to be a bad thing. For some reason I keep seeing demands to balance the sides. That defeats the purpose of the game. It is supposed to be extremely difficult for the Marines. I enjoy the desperate situation that I find myself in as the Marine. It just makes victory that much sweeter!
A fine game but it's a bit lengthy due to the added time needed to set the game up.

item.name: Elk Fest
item.comment:
I knew what I was getting when I bought it...a silly little dexterity game.
Upon our very first play I thought to myself "oh uh...this just isnt going to be much fun." But...we have had a real good time playing this one. It is very quick to play so sometimes when we just have ten minutes to kill we break it out. My wife keeps the pieces in her purse and we play at bars and restaurants while we wait for our food.
I didn't think my friends would get it either. They arrived as my wife and I were wrapping up a game and suddenly they were all demanding to play! It has really gone over well. I am in the process of making a second set so we can play 4 at once for more chaos!
There is zero depth but it is exactly what a game is supposed to be...fun.

item.name: Formula Dé
item.comment:
A dicefest but I love it. I never win. Ever. Well..ok..once. I won once and I still thoroughly enjoy this game. My bad luck with dice is LEGENDARY in my circle of friends and family. Not only will I always roll too low to make it into a curve but I will ALWAYS roll precisely the number to put me in the spot just before the corner increasing my agony. I think that says something about this game if I'm am always the loser and always have bad luck with the game and still love to play it.
I find that a lot of non-gamers tend to enjoy it, especially the ones who are fond of racing. The rules are very simple and the game is easily explained in a few minutes. I do, however, find the fun factor to be directly proportional to the amount of players. There is little chance of wreckage with just a few players so the more players you have the more challenge you will find in the game. More players also adds to the strategy available by adding more opportunities for blocking and for drafting. I highly recommend this one.
It's a very light game and if you aren't fond of luck in your games you won't care for it, though.

item.name: Formula Dé Circuits 3 & 4: Zandvoort 2 & SPA-Francorchamps
item.comment: A couple of nice tracks. I really like the challenge of the Spa track. The Zandvoort is real easy but it's a good track for first time players to learn on. I haven't tried combining the two Zandvoort tracks yet.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment:
My sister's favorite game growing up. There is zero game here. No choices to be made. The winner will be decided by the spinner.
That having been said, I do have a small weak spot for the game. It's the one game my sister (the biggest NON-GAMER ever....seriously..she hates fun..could be why she likes this game) would always want to play. So I give it a 4 for nostalgia. Plus it is one that young kids can play and have an equal chance of winning without adult advice.

item.name: Guesstures
item.comment: A party game. Not my favorite. I always have a decent time playing but there are other party games Id rather play if party games is what we are doing.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment:
This is another game that I rarely do well in but yet love to play. It is often refered to as dry but I don't find it so. There is not as much strategy available as in some games and it is impossible to plan ahead because you will never know what the board will look like or where the ship will be when until it becomes your turn again. Not necessarily a bad thing; not every game has to allow for advanced planning. Sometimes its a nice change of pace to simply have to make the best of each present situation.
A fun game that has gone over well with everyone I've shown it to and my circle of friends are not gamers at all.

item.name: HeroClix
item.comment:
Fairly fun. We ended up ditching a couple of rules and tweeking a rule or two and that is something I have never done before. I just really don't like collectible games.
It's a fun game that we have enjoyed from time to time but be aware that it is a money pit.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment: A decent enough game. I was surprised to find that my wife liked it well enough. A very scaled-down, simplified miniature game. Takes some time to set up each game which does limit the number of plays somewhat. Haven't felt any driving urge to buy more sets or any expansions, thankfully!

item.name: Hive
item.comment:
Very chess-like. Every piece has a particular manner in which it may move. You have to be very careful to balance your play between defense and offense or you will suddenly find your queen bee in nasty situation.
A little expensive for what you get but we have really enjoyed it.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
Jambo
item.comment:
I stink at this game apparently. My wife slaps me around in it. The game is fun but surprisingly long for a card game. There seems to be a great variety of cards which keeps the game interesting.
A clever little card game that may grow on me more when I learn to beat my wife!

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: An ok dexterity game I suppose. Just not my favorite. There are better ones available.

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: I think I'm going to like this one the more I play it. It is surprisingly confrontational and can get quite viscious. I'll add more comments when I have played it more.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment:
My non-gaming pals have unanimously decided that they really like cooperative games. They have enjoyed Shadows of Camelot a great deal and this one plays very similar to that in my opinion. The difference lies mostly in theme. Lord of the Rings, however, is much harder to beat. At the time of this review we have played 5 or 6 times without a victory thus far but we are getting better. I look forward to trying the expansions to this one. It is a very simple game to teach.
Very good game if you are looking for more interaction between players and enjoy cooperative games.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment:
One of our favorites. A light card game with some real tough choices to be made. Some very hard decisions have to be made throughout the game: start an expedition? Wait for more funding? Give up a potential expedition? My wife and I play this more than any of our other two player options. It's very easy to teach and plays very quickly.
Highly recommended.

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment:
I have had a lot of fun with this. It's a very light game but always gets the group laughing and groaning. It can be very confrontational as players will often shift the maze sometimes sololy to annoy another player!
Not many choices to be made but trying to figure out how to shift the maze to your advantage can be a real brain-burner. It's easy to learn and teach. I enjoy this one.

item.name: New England
item.comment:
After repeated plays, I find this to be a rather lackluster game.
The more I played the more I realized how few real decisions there are to make. The only real thinking exercise in the entire game is deciding what bidding token to take and even that had little impact in the end in any of the five times I have played. You just buy the best available land/progress card. Yes, there are some choices to be made but I never felt like any of them made that big a difference. The very first time we played I felt like I was way behind the entire game and I was as surprised as everyone to find that I had won. So, I figured that I would love to play again knowing what I knew now about the game. I came into the next few games focused and fully aware of all the rules and a few strategies I had been working on. I again won the game...with the exact same score I had when it was complete luck. Ok, I figure it's a fluke. Three games later, even games I didn't win, I still get the same score, plus or minus a point. This is even after trying wildly different strategies (not that there are very many).
My choices, even when radically different, still resulted in roughly the same amount of points everytime; even when I was last every bidding round I would still end up with the same approximate points. I just never felt like any of my choices REALLY mattered.
It's not a BAD game. I just don't think it's a very good one either.

item.name: Nuclear War
item.comment: Remember having a great deal of fun with this in my youth but having reacquired it recently I'm wondering what has changed? Just wasn't much fun anymore. Could be that my group just isn't a good fit for this one.

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment:
A press your luck type game. Toss a pair of pigs and the position they land in either awards you points or ends your turn, losing you all the points you have thus far accumulated in this turn.
Zero skill involved. It's really just about taking risks and getting lucky.

item.name: Pictionary
item.comment: A fun party game. Still a family favorite.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment:
I think this game is kind of fun. I enjoy playing it but my group loves it far more than I do, which really effects my enjoyment of the game; they want to play it every single night. There is a great deal of luck involved. The only real decision making is during the bluffing/picking your destination phase. It's an enjoyable game most times but not as often as I am forced to play it.
Very light game. Heavy luck. Little strategy. Heavy theme.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment:
Man, do I love this game. It is very fun. My only complaint is that the end can often leave you feeling very unsatisfied. The end is almost always rather anticlimatic.
This has been a real surprise hit with my non-gaming friends. They sat there with bored indifference while I explained the rules and I feared that it would be a complete failure with them but 1/4 of the way into the game they started talking amongst themselves about how much fun they were having.
Some tough decisions to be made. Some fun auction action. Not nearly as "fiddly" as people say and the "math" that everyone seems to be complaining about is simple addition...not sure what the problem is.
A great game with little luck involved. Everyone is always in the game and always feel like they have a shot all the way to the end.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment:
A great deal of fun but I've found that I have a lot less fun with inexperienced players involved.
The game moves along at a decent pace when everyone has played before..otherwise it drags as everyone insists on reading every single building card even after having already read it three of four times.
There are a great many strategys that can be used and many interesting and tough decisions to be made as you go. You also have to be clever and adapt your strategy at the drop of a hat when someone snags up that one building that was key to your strategy.
The game is not nearly as complex as it may appear , nor as dry. It has been a real favorite.

item.name: Risk
item.comment: Much maligned for being a dice-fest but I've always had a fondness for the game.

item.name: Trias
item.conditiontext: I have the original wooden dinosaurs in my version. I got them directly from the games designer to replace the pieces that came with it.

item.name: Twister
item.comment: Depends sololy upon the group playing or upon your state of undress and drunkeness.

item.name: Wildlife Safari
item.comment:
I have a lot of friends who are really into poker and for whatever reason this has gone over very well with them. It plays in about ten minutes which is amazing because it can be a real brain burner for such a simple game. It can be taught in about 30 seconds too which is very nice.
A very satisfying (and cheap!) filler game.
